G.L.\u202fc.\u202f212, \u00a7\u202f4.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Berkshire Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the cause of action arose in this county.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363\u202fMass.\u202.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on or adjacent to their property.

*Robbins v. Athol Gas & Elec. Co.*, 236\.raw_text: *Robbins v. Athol Gas & Elec. Co.*, 236 Mass. 387 (1920)
*Robbins v. Athol Gas & Elec. Co.*, 236\.proposition: Defendant, as the landowner, had a duty to maintain his property and appurtenances— including vegetation extending over public sidewalks—so as not to create a foreseeable hazard to travelers.

*Roman v. Boston*, 127\u202fMass.\u202f3.proposition: Defendant, as the landowner, had a duty to maintain his property and appurtenances— including vegetation extending over public sidewalks—so as not to create a foreseeable hazard to travelers.

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465\u202fMass.\u.proposition: The standard of care requires landowners to take reasonable steps to inspect and correct dangerous conditions.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457\u202.proposition: The standard of care requires landowners to take reasonable steps to inspect and correct dangerous conditions.

*Carkin v. Reynolds*, 306\u202fMass.\u20.raw_text: *Carkin v. Reynolds*, 306 Mass. 225 (1940) (landowner liable where decayed tree limb overhanging highway fell on traveler).
*Carkin v. Reynolds*, 306\u202fMass.\u20.proposition: Defendant knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known that the cracked branch was likely to fall and injure someone using the public sidewalk.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430\u202fMass.\u202.proposition: Failing to take timely remedial action constituted an unreasonable and negligent omission within the meaning of *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437\u202fMass.\u.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, physical pain, mental suffering, and economic losses.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447\u202fMass.\u202f141.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, physical pain, mental suffering, and economic losses.

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231, \u00a7\u00a7\u202.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 85, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages and statutory interest.

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231,\u202f\u00a7\u202f.proposition: Award pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
